chapterTitle: Introduction to Valuation:The Time Value of Money

columns.text: In this exercise, we must describe four components of the basic equation of present value.

In financial terms, there is a correlation between the current and future value of a product or service. The relationship between the present value and the future value is established by the interest rate and the linked time periods.

**The basic equation of present value** is the result of expressing present value in terms of future value and is expressed as follows:

$$\begin{align*}
\text{PV}=\dfrac{\text{FV}_{\text{t}}}{(1+\text{r})^{\text{t}}}
\end{align*}$$

Where:
- PV is the present value
- FV is the future worth
- T is the number of periods
- r is the interest rate

The first component is **Present Value (PV).** The amount spent at the moment to obtain the desired amount after a certain period of time in the future is called the present value.

Property is known as the "time value of money," which means that, in most cases, the present value will be less than or equal to its future value unless interest rates are negative; in that case, the present value will be equal to or greater than the future value.

The second component is **Future Value (FV).** It is the value of money that will increase with simple or compound interest over time. It is one of the most significant ideas in finance, and it is founded on the notion of time value of money, which is explained below. In a nutshell, future value shows us how much money we may expect to get from any kind of investment in the near future.

The third component is **Number of Periods (t).** It refers to the amount of time that has passed between the present and the future and indicates the period of time during which the investment will be carried out.

The last one is **Interest rate or rate of return (r)**. It represents the amount of profit or loss generated by investing in a certain period of time. In other words, the rate of return is the difference between the profit (or loss) made on an investment and the cost of the original investment, which is often given as a percentage. When the rate of return is positive, the investment has been deemed a success; when the rate of return is negative, the investment is considered a failure.
In this problem, we have to calculate the two types of interests i.e. simple and compound for two different banks, and then compare both of them.

It is important to note here the difference between the simple interest and the compound interest. The basic difference between the two is the principle on which the interest is calculated. 

 In the case of **simple interest**, the interest is calculated on the original principal value. This earned interest is not again invested. So, this interest is always calculated on the original principal.

In the case of **compound interest**, initially, the interest is calculated on the original principal value. This earned interest is again invested (one gets an **interest even on interest**). So, in the next period, the interest will be calculated on the sum of the original principal and the interest thereon.

The simple interest is calculated in the following manner:

$$\text{SI =P$\times$ R$\times$ T}$$

where $SI$ is the simple interest,

$P$ is the principal amount, 

$R$ is the interest rate, and

$T$ is the time period.

The amount after adding compound interest is calculated in the following manner:

$$\text{A =P} \left(1+r\right)^t$$

where $A$ is the amount after interest i.e. the future value,

$P$ is the principal amount, 

$r$ is the interest rate, and

$t$ is the time period.

The amount of **Compound Interest** will be the difference between the final amount and the original principal:

$$\text{CI = A - P}$$

The next step is to identify the interest schemes offered by the two banks:
|**Particulars** | **First City Bank** | **Second City Bank**| 
|--|--|--| 
|Amount Invested |$7,500 |$7,500 | 
|Time Period |8 years |8 years | 
|Interest Type |Simple |Compound (Annually)| 
| Interest rate|9% |9% |

Let us determine the interest offered by the First City bank. We will substitute $P=\$7,500$, $R=9\%$ or $R=0.09$, and $T=8$ in the formula of simple interest in the fourth step. Accordingly, we have:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{SI}&=\$7,500\times 0.09\times 8\\
&=\$5,400
\end{aligned}$$

Thus the **amount of interest offered by the First City Bank is $\$5,400$**.

Next, we will determine the interest offered by the Second City bank. We will substitute $P=\$7,500$, $r=9\%$ or $r=0.09$, and $t=8$ in the formula of future value after compound interest interest in the fifth step. Accordingly, we have:

$$\begin{aligned}
A&=\$7,500 \left(1+0.09\right)^8\\
&=\$7,500 \left(1.09\right)^8\\
&\approx\$14,944.22
\end{aligned}$$

Thus the **amount after eight years** as per the interest offered by the Second City Bank will be $\$14,944.22$.

Now we will find the Compound Interest as per the formula in step 5:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{CI}&=\$14,944.22-\$7,500\\
&=\$7,444.22
\end{aligned}$$

Thus the **amount of interest offered by the Second City Bank is $\$7,444.22$.**

Finally we will calculate the difference between the interest offered by the two banks. It is calculated as follows:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Difference}&= \text{CI} - \text{SI}\\
&=\$7,444.22-\$5,400\\
&=\$2,044.22
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, it can be **concluded** that the investor will earn $\$2,044.22$ more if they choose to deposit money in the Second City Bank instead of the First City Bank after eight years.
